q: What are the main symptoms of diabetes insipidus?
a: The main symptoms of diabetes insipidus are extreme thirst (polydipsia) and peeing a lot, even at night (polyuria).

q: When should I seek medical advice for diabetes insipidus symptoms?
a: You should see your GP if you're feeling thirsty all the time or if you're peeing more than normal. It should be investigated to determine the cause.

q: What causes diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus is caused by problems with a hormone called vasopressin (AVP) or antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which regulates fluid levels in the body.

q: How does diabetes insipidus affect the kidneys?
a: In diabetes insipidus, the lack of production of vasopressin or the kidneys not responding to it causes the kidneys to produce too much diluted urine.

q: Who is affected by diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus affects about 1 in 25,000 people in the general population and can occur at any age.

q: What are the types of diabetes insipidus?
a: There are two main types of diabetes insipidus: cranial diabetes insipidus and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

q: How is cranial diabetes insipidus caused?
a: Cranial diabetes insipidus can be caused by damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, as well as other factors like infections, tumors, or head injuries.

q: How is nephrogenic diabetes insipidus treated?
a: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is often treated with medications called thiazide diuretics, which reduce the amount of urine produced by the kidneys.

q: What are the complications of diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus can lead to dehydration due to increased water loss in the urine. Severe dehydration may require treatment in a hospital.

q: How can mild cases of cranial diabetes insipidus be managed?
a: Mild cases of cranial diabetes insipidus can be managed by increasing water intake to compensate for the lost fluids through frequent urination.

q: What are the main symptoms of diabetes insipidus?
a: The main symptoms of diabetes insipidus are extreme thirst (polydipsia) and excessive urination (polyuria).

q: When should I seek medical advice for diabetes insipidus?
a: You should see your GP if you're experiencing constant thirst or urinating more than normal.

q: How is diabetes insipidus diagnosed?
a: Your GP will conduct tests to determine the cause of your symptoms. This may include blood and urine tests.

q: What causes diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus is caused by problems with a hormone called vasopressin (AVP) or antidiuretic hormone (ADH). It can be due to a lack of production or a failure in response to AVP.

q: Who can be affected by diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus can affect anyone, but it is more common in adults. It occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 people.

q: What are the types of diabetes insipidus?
a: There are two main types of diabetes insipidus: cranial diabetes insipidus and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

q: How is cranial diabetes insipidus caused?
a: Cranial diabetes insipidus can be caused by damage to the hypothalamus or pituitary gland, brain tumors, infections, operations, or head injuries.

q: How is nephrogenic diabetes insipidus caused?
a: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs when the body has sufficient AVP, but the kidneys fail to respond to it. It can be caused by kidney damage, inherited problems, or certain medications.

q: How is diabetes insipidus treated?
a: Treatment for diabetes insipidus may include increasing fluid intake, medication like desmopressin to replicate AVP functions, and thiazide diuretics to reduce urine production.

q: What are the complications of diabetes insipidus?
a: Diabetes insipidus can lead to dehydration due to excessive water loss in urine. Mild cases can be treated with rehydration, while severe cases may require hospital treatment.
